thread.title: Clouds hurt Block Party attendance but create chill vibe | Festival review
thread.title_full: Clouds hurt Block Party attendance but create chill vibe | Festival review | The Seattle Times

author: Mike Ramos
title: Clouds hurt Block Party attendance but create chill vibe | Festival review
text:
Concert review The 19th annual Capitol Hill Block Party coincided with one of the coolest and cloudiest weekends of the blazing 2015 summer and caused the festival to take a significant hit in attendance.
But rather than killing the buzz, the overcast atmosphere chilled things out, with the focus a little less on the party and a bit more on the music — a welcome change.
This year’s offerings balanced strong local talent with crowd-pleasing indie acts, a few relevant DJ/producers and some wild cards that drew people in with their sound and spectacle rather than their names.
Local minimal-intergalactic-rap duo Shabazz Palaces provided an ideal opening on the main stage with a typically tight yet free-form electronic and live percussion set, hypnotizing the crowd into a silent but appreciative sway.
Most Read Stories Sister-in-law didn’t appreciate delivery support 5 things you should know about Microsoft’s Windows 10 Video from bus driver’s body camera could cost 2 deputies their jobs Salary gap widens as elite skills reward a select few 2 killed in drive-by shooting on I-5 in Mount Vernon Jarv Dee’s set featuring the Moor Gang at a near-capacity Neumo’s early Saturday was the exact opposite, but seemed to cement his status as a local legend, as the enthusiastic crowd turned all the way up for selections from his 2012 “Dopamine” and this year’s “Satellites, Swishers and Spaceships.”
U.K. producer/DJ Jamie xx — touring in support of his thoroughly excellent “In Colour” solo LP — started with an extended intro of The Persuasions’ “Good Times,” the sample source for his summer-oriented hit single “I Know There’s Gonna Be (Good Times)” which gave way to his Popcaan/Young Thug-assisted version of the same song. That brief dancehall-inflected bright spot quickly shifted as he flipped the sample again, this time into a shuffling, trap-sounding two-step beat, and mixed in a verse from Skepta before transitioning to a classic from grime legend Wiley. As dusk eclipsed the day, Jamie xx turned the open-air festival into a nighttime U.K. rave.
San Francisco’s Giraffage provided a more youthful dance-party vibe to the mainstage on Saturday with his whimsical dream-trap, which ranged from righteous (a rework of Janet Jackson’s “Someone To Call My Lover”) to cheesy (a remix of R. Kelly’s “Ignition”). It all went over so well with the crowd that they waited patiently — almost no booing or heckling — when his sound cut out for a solid five minutes.
Household-name indie outfits such as Built To Spill, TV on the Radio, Wye Oak and Toro Y Moi all brought big, full-band sounds and skillful, professional sets, which drew the 30-plus demographic that filled up the Pike Street corridor.
But it’s always the unexpected that provides the most rewarding experience. Take Toronto free-jazz quartet BADBADNOTGOOD, which somehow united rap and electronic fans in their teens and early 20s to rock out to extensive, vamping jams, complete with keyboard and saxophone solos. Or Los Angeles ensemble Meatbodies, clad in capes and KISS-meets-Bowie-meets-Dimmu Borgir face paint, playing raucous, riff-heavy twin-guitar rock.
Or San Francisco’s Deafheaven, whose Explosions In the Sky-meets-shoegaze/black metal sounded like a force of nature on the Vera Stage, and may well have caused the dark skies to make rain Friday night.
Like the suddenly cool weather, these acts were unexpected, but worked out well.
Mike Ramos on Twitter @Ram0s206
